data.title: Shares In U.S. Insurers Make Light Of Supreme Court Tariff Ruling
data.description:
Shares in US insurers were less impacted by the broader market's volatility that came in the wake of a US Supreme Court decision striking down President Donald Trump's sweeping tariffs.

Apart from some specific managed care and insurance technology players, most listed US insurers shrugged off the Supreme Court decision, with the S&P Global insurance index rising 0.62% from Feb. 20 through Feb. 26. Insurance performed slightly better than the S&P 500 index, which, after an initial rise, remained largely steady, and better than the banking and energy indexes, as the stock market reacted to investor uncertainty.

In the near year since Trump announced his escalating series of global tariffs, the insurance sector has remained well insulated against any direct impacts from the tariffs, according to Piper Sandler analyst Paul Newsome. While some insurers may have worked inflationary concerns into their revised rates post-tariffs, consumers are unlikely to see related rates lowered now, Newsome said.

"I don't think any insurer really changed prices because of the tariff, and I don't think if [the tariffs] go away, you'll see much of an impact as well," Newsome said. "I think the insurance industry will just kind of keep trucking along, and you won't see much of an impact either way."

Tariff ruling

In a 6-3 ruling released Feb. 20, the Supreme Court held that the Trump administration exceeded its authority by using the International Emergency Economic Powers Act to impose wide-ranging global tariffs, calling much of the administration's economic policy into question.

Since the ruling, Trump has doubled down on the tariffs, signing Feb. 20 an executive order that imposes the 10% tariffs under Section 122 of the Trade Act of 1974. Those went into effect Feb. 24, and Trump has subsequently threatened to raise the tariffs to 15%.

Some companies in the retail and imports sectors have filed lawsuits seeking reimbursements for tariffs paid to the US government. While those lawsuits remain ongoing, if refunds materialize, insurers are unlikely to be recipients, according to Newsome.

"Companies have to show how they were directly impacted, and because insurers are not actually importing or exporting anything, I would be surprised if any saw refunds," Newsome said.

Impacts vary by sector

Insurance and insurance-adjacent sectors such as healthcare and asset management reacted differently to the Supreme Court decision, but after a few days, there were only a couple of percentage points difference in terms of overall performance.

While the insurance sector has been largely insulated against the tariffs, the property and casualty sector has some more exposure due to its reliance on imported parts for home and vehicle repairs, among other things susceptible to inflationary pressures, Newsome said.

"When you start looking at where tariffs would potentially create inflation, it's there, but it's just proportionally not as big as other [financial sectors]," Newsome said.

Even with the unpredictable ups and downs, Newsome expects insurers to emerge from this period of volatility in a good position.

Original Post

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

data.title: Japan Rises, Again
data.description:
When Commodore Matthew Perry sailed into what is now Tokyo Bay in July 1853, the Industrial Revolution had already been galvanizing Western economies for a half century. Japan, by contrast, was an isolated feudal backwater, intentionally cut off from the rest of the world since the beginning of the Tokugawa Shogunate in 1603.

Faced with the obvious technical superiority of the West as they stared down the cannon barrels of Perry’s Black Ships, Japan’s leaders realized that nothing short of a far-reaching transformation away from the ossified practices of the ruling samurai class was going to be required.

Via the Meiji Restoration that began in 1868, they succeeded. By the end of the nineteenth century, Japan was a modernized industrial power carving out its own empire to compete with those of its Western peers. In 1905 it defeated one of those peers, the czarist empire of Russia, in the Russo-Japanese War and thus firmly established itself as a player in the great-power politics of the age.

The Takaichi Trade

The point of that little history lesson is that one should never count out Japan and its ability to reinvent itself. For the past thirty-odd years it has been easy to dismiss Japan as a once-strong economy whose time has come and gone. The Nikkei 225 stock index failed to regain its 1989 high point until 2024, 35 years later.

Demography, deflation and debt summed up an economy listlessly drifting its way into senescence, stubbornly clinging to a shopworn model while the rest of the world raced ahead with successive generations of game-changing technologies.

But recently, the country seems to have shaken off the malaise of these so-called lost decades. That long-suffering Nikkei 225 index has gone from also-ran to world-beating over the past twelve months.

A good portion of this outperformance can be attributed to the emergence of a new political star. Sanae Takaichi is a rarity in the world of Japanese politics in two ways: first, she is a woman, the first of her gender to attain the office of prime minister; and, second, that she is wildly popular.

Her initial victory last October sent the Nikkei surging, even as the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) that she heads struggled to piece together a coalition government. It surged again earlier this month when a snap election audaciously called by Takaichi resulted in an LDP victory of historic proportions and a clear green light for the new government to move ahead with its mandate for sweeping economic reform.

The Takaichi Trap

That mandate, though, is not without some potential headwinds. The Takaichi government seeks to implement a major stimulus program to reinvigorate industry, catalyze consumer spending (for example, by eliminating a consumption tax on food products) and establish a stronger geopolitical presence in the region.

This last item, which implies a big investment in Japan’s defense industry, has already created some waves after Takaichi made some supportive remarks in favor of Taiwan, remarks that provoked pointed criticism from China.

As for the stimulus measures, they are going to have to contend with the Bank of Japan’s attempts to normalize monetary policy and keep a lid on inflation, which has made a somewhat surprising return in the past couple of years.

Japanese bond yields have experienced some wobbles of late, as investors try to figure out how the BoJ and the Takaichi government are going to harmonize their respective agendas.

Remembering Shimonoseki

It is, of course, possible that the best-laid plans of the Takaichi government will fail in its attempts to re-establish Japan as a highly productive and energetic economy with world-class products and services. But, as we noted above, it is never wise to count the country out.

Reaching even farther back into the annals of history, in the late thirteenth century Japan was besieged by the superpower of the day, the Mongol empire of Kublai Khan. After a first encounter in which the Mongols gained some territory but then backed off to regroup, the Japanese built fortified protections strong enough to withstand future assaults.

Attack again the Mongol fleet did, but it failed to penetrate the fortifications, and while the fleet was stranded in the straits of Shimonoseki trying to advance, it was destroyed by a great typhoon – the “divine wind” the Japanese translation of which is “kamikaze.” The Mongols never attacked again.

Japan is a highly conservative society with a pronounced resistance to change. But when it puts its mind to it, the country has shown in the past that it is capable of remarkable change in a very short period of time. As nations around the world grope for position in the changing global order, it may be time to give Japan another, closer look.

Original Post

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

data.title: Services PPI Inflation Explodes. Goods PPI Jumps As Companies Shuffle Tariffs To Each Other. Food And Energy Plunge
data.description:
It will further fuel the acceleration of the Fed-favored PCE Price Index.

The Producer Price Index (PPI) for services spiked by 0.81% (+10.2% annualized) in January from December, seasonally adjusted, the second spike in a row. The PPI for “core” goods, which excludes food and energy products, spiked by 0.68% (+8.5%), the most since 2022.

PPI does not track import prices and tariffs; it tracks prices that companies charge each other. So it tracks how companies are shuffling the costs of the tariffs around amongst each other.

But the PPI for finished core goods rose by a more modest but still high 0.42% (+5.2% annualized), suggesting that there is resistance to price increases amongst consumer-facing companies, as they’ve had a hard time passing on price increases to consumers without losing sales.

The worst inflation impulses were in services in January, and the services PPI weighs 68% of the overall PPI. It moves the needle. The PPI for Final Demand Services spiked by 0.81% (+10.2% annualized) in January from December after the 0.67% spike in December, seasonally adjusted, according to data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics on Friday (blue in the chart). The 6-month average rose by 4.1% annualized, a hair less than in December, which had been the worst since February 2025 (red).

Within the services PPI, two of the three major categories moved up sharply:

  • Trade services PPI (weighs 19% in overall PPI): +2.5% month-to-month, not annualized, driven by professional & commercial equipment wholesaling: +14.4%.
  • Transportation & warehousing services PPI (weighs 4.9% in overall PPI): +1.0% month-to-month, not annualized.
  • Finished services less trade, transportation & warehousing (weighs 38% in overall PPI): unchanged.

Year-over-year, the services PPI accelerated to 3.44%, the third month in a row of acceleration. The low point, the point of the coolest recent services PPI inflation, was in December 2023 at 1.8%.

Impact on the Fed-favored PCE Price Index

The PPI for portfolio management, which feeds into the PCE Price Index of January (to be released March 13), spiked by 1.5% month to month, not annualized, in January, the fourth month in a row of big spikes. Year-over-year, it spiked by 17.9%. This adds to indications that the Fed-favored core PCE price index, which was already 3.0% in December, will further accelerate away from the Fed’s 2% target.

Goods prices

The PPI's final demand for both food and energy plunged month-to-month:

  • PPI for Food: -1.5%
  • PPI for Energy: -2.7%

But goods prices without food and energy were another thing.

The core goods PPI final demand (excludes food and energy) spiked by 0.68% in January from December (+8.5% annualized). The 6-month average rose by 4.7% annualized. Both were the worst since 2022.

The tariffs are percolating through the goods categories at various stages of the PPI as companies try to pass them on to each other. But consumer-facing companies have resisted price increases because consumers have resisted price increases, and these companies have had trouble passing on higher costs to consumers without losing sales.

Year-over-year, the core goods PPI jumped by 4.2%, the worst since March 2023.

The “finished core goods” PPI - goods ready to be sold to the end-user - also accelerated, but not to the extent the “core goods” PPI has: 0.42% month-to-month (+5.2% annualized). The 6-month average rose by 4.1% annualized.

Year-over-year, the finished core goods CPI jumped by 3.8%, the worst since July 2023.

Core PPI Final Demand, which includes all goods and services except food and energy, spiked by 0.80% month-to-month (+10.0% annualized), driven by a 0.81% spike in the services PPI. The 6-month average rose by 4.3% annualized, same as in December, and both were the worst since January 2025.

Year-over-year, core PPI accelerated to +3.58%, the worst since March 2025.

The overall PPI Final Demand, muffled by the plunge in food and energy prices, jumped by a more modest but still bad 0.48% month-to-month (+5.9% annualized). Year-over-year (red in the chart), the overall PPI rose by 2.9%.

Inflation has been broadly accelerating since 2023 at the producer level, except in energy products, where prices have plunged. Here we’re looking at this mess on a year-over-year basis for overall PPI (green double line), core PPI (purple line), services PPI (red line), and core goods PPI (yellow line), and it clearly shows the trend that started in 2023:

Original Post

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

data.title: Clearwater Analytics: How Its Agentic AI Could Be The Future Nervous System Of $10 Trillion In Assets
data.description:
Clearwater Analytics, Inc (CWAN) signed a final acquisition agreement with a consortium of private equity funds including Permira and Warburg Pincus in a deal of $8.4 billion or $24.5 per share, as the company is transforming from being just a provider of accounting software to be a central nervous system of assets management and financial portfolios supported by +900 AI Agents that operate independently within CWAN's platform, which significantly reduces labor costs and creates obstacles for trasoditional competitors that cannot overcome in the near term. This was evident in Q4 revenues, which jumped by 72%. In addition, the active investor "Starboard Value" bought a stake of 5%, which can be a signal of the current cheap price compared to the company's future potential.

Agentic AI

At first, we should understand the reason why private funds are racing to acquire CWAN. The banks and insurance companies face a structural problem, as these institutions suffer from buying different software from different suppliers, for example, a software for trading and another for risk management and third for deal settlement, the problem is these systems are outdated and cannot communicate with each other effectively, consequently, armies of employees and accountants spend hundreds of hours weekly, extracting data manually then trying to format it into reports to send to regulatory authorities. It is a complex and stressful process, besides being full of deadly human errors.

So, the company saw the solution was in providing what is known as single-instance, multi-tenant architecture; however, the defensive moat for the company was only recently completed with the launch of its GenAI platform, as in Nov 2025, CWAN deployed nearly 1000 AI Agents integrated into its platform. The difference between the normal GenAI models, such as GPT or Gemini and the Agentic AI is that the latter can handle complicated multi-tasks without human intervention, plus it learns from its mistakes. This enables institutions to analyze billions of data daily without the need for 90% of the required manual effort, which contributes significantly to reducing labor costs. Importantly, it is difficult for clients to move to a competitive solution, as this leads to operational breakdowns and the need to hire an army of employees again, so the client will consider the switching costs, which will be exorbitant. This explains why CWAN maintains a high gross revenue retention rate of 98% over 27 of 28 quarters.

Acquisitions

Clearwater also realized that customer retention requires providing them with a solution that covers the investment cycle from A to Z, so it undertook a series of acquisitions during 2025, including the Enfusion deal that provided CWAN with front office capabilities from trading and order routing to support of real-time investment decisions. Besides Enfusion, it acquired Beacon, which added advanced capabilities of risk analysis, private markets, and derivatives. There is also Blackstone's Bistro, which specializes in alternative assets analysis. The integration between CWAN's AI platform and these acquisitions can provide portfolio managers and investment banks with a comprehensive solution that traditional competitors lack.

Financials & Outlook

In Q4 and the full year, CWAN announced exceptional results, which confirm that the company is in a hyper-growth state. It recorded total revenues of $217.5 million with a growth of 72% YoY; this unusual growth was driven by the expansion of cross-selling operations.

Additionally, the ARR has grown by 77% to achieve $841 million compared to $474.9 million last year, meaning that customers have committed to long-term contracts, reducing revenue's volatility and enabling investors to predict the future cash flows.

In addition, the growth of profits has exceeded the revenues, as the company recorded Adjusted EBITDA of $74.1 million compared to $41.7 million YoY with a growth of 78%, suggesting that the company is able to expand its operations without additional costs at the same percentage, indicating the management quality.

The CEO also noted that the company's large investments in GenAI begin to bear fruit in the form of internal efficiencies, justifying that the Non GAAP gross margin reached 79.2%, which is an excellent profit margin, and suggesting that the cost of revenue is almost zero thanks to AI that does the mission instead of employing armies of engineers to serve customers.

The company did not provide guidance for 2026. However, Wall Street expects Q1 revenues to hover around $218 million, which is a significant growth of 72% YoY, driven by the combined revenues from Enfusion and Beacon. Moreover, Adjusted EBITDA margin may settle over 34% due to replacing the traditional jobs with AI, plus the rapid success in achieving operational synergies, which is expected to generate cash flows of $60 million.

Valuation

Since CWAN is currently trading at a $6.86 billion market cap and it has debts of $822.6 million and cash of $91 million, the EV is estimated at $7.6 billion. Considering that 2025 revenues are $731 million while 2026 revenues are estimated at $946 million, the EV/revenue of the company is around 8x-10x. Given the closest competitor, SS&C Technologies (SSNC), which trades at a multiple of 4x, CWAN seems optically overvalued. But SSNC is a mature company and growing at a slower pace of approximately 7%. While the valuation gap favors CWAN because it relies completely on a pure cloud SaaS and grows at a faster rate of approximately 30%, therefore the market gives CWAN a premium based on its rapid growth, putting pressure on it to maintain this performance in the future.

Risks To Consider

The company faces a set of risks, the first of which is the failure of the acquisition deal. Although the company obtained early termination of the waiting period under the HSR antitrust law, the major deals may collapse for one reason or another, as a sudden financing crisis may prevent the private funds from arranging the required loans for the deal. Or a minority shareholder such as Starboard may vote against the deal if they think that the proposed price undervalues them; consequently, the stock may witness a violent downward reaction from arbitrage funds, which will immediately liquidate their portfolios.

Also, merging the three entities Enfusion, Beacon, and Bistro with the company wouldn't be an easy mission, as integrating the cultures, databases, and programming languages is a very complex process for any management. If the integration efforts fail, this can lead to a temporary decline in the profit margins or even distract the management from core sales, which could push customers to flee to competitors.

Despite the optimism of Agentic AI capabilities, the accounting and asset management sector is very sensitive to errors; thus, any random error resulting from AI malfunctions could lead to data fabrications or presenting false information to regulators and central banks, which could expose clients to hefty fines. While the company's business model operates in a very strict and regulated environment, this risk remains.

Final Thoughts

Clearwater Analytics offers a unique technology in order to be the beating heart of $10 trillion; it is also able to free its clients from bureaucratic labor. The fruits of these advancements were evident in Q4 results, which jumped by 72%. However, we should accurately monitor the upcoming shareholder vote on the company's acquisition agreement, in addition to any announcements from Starboard about CWAN's valuation. We should also keep an eye on any leaks of cross-selling transactions from Enfusion or Beacon to its existing institutions.

data.title: Chicago PMI Climbs To Highest Level In Nearly 4 Years
data.description:
By Jennifer Nash

The Chicago Purchasing Managers’ Index (Chicago Business Barometer) climbed to its highest level in nearly four years in February, rising 3.7 points to 57.7. This reading came in above the projected 52.0 and marks the second straight month regional business activity has expanded.

Background on Chicago PMI

The Chicago PMI assesses the business conditions and the economic health of the manufacturing sector in the Chicago region. A value above 50.0 indicates expanding manufacturing activity, while a value below 50.0 indicates contracting manufacturing activity.

Weak readings have often preceded broader economic downturns. Looking at the index's historical performance, the current level of 57.7 is lower than where the index stood at the start of 1 of the 7 recessions since its inception.

A Closer Look Since 2000

Examining data since 2000, the index has undergone fluctuations, often aligning with broader economic cycles. Given its persistent weakness, the current level reinforces concerns about ongoing softness in the manufacturing sector.

Chicago PMI vs. ISM Manufacturing Index

Let's compare the Chicago PMI with the more popular national ISM manufacturing index. Over the 673 months of available data, the Chicago PMI has been higher 69% of the time. However, despite this frequent outperformance, its historical average of 54.2 is only slightly higher than the ISM’s 52.4.

It's clear the two indices tend to move together; however, it’s important to note that the ISM Manufacturing Index is reported with a one-month lag.

Original Post

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

data.title: Chord Energy: This U.S. Oil Gem's Valuation Disconnect Is Too Big To Ignore
data.description:
Introduction

The last time I covered Chord Energy (CHRD), I highlighted their robust cash flow, significant efficiencies, improvements, and healthy balance sheet, reiterating their Strong Buy rating.

I reiterate CHRD’s Strong Buy rating following the solid earnings report, as the company remains one of the best opportunities in US oil today, in my opinion, maintaining a strong balance sheet with no maturities until 2030 and significant potential to develop as a strong Williston Basin producer.

Internal Developments

Chord reported what I would call a strong Q4 and 2025 overall given the macro conditions, beating the market’s non-GAAP EPS and revenue estimates, with $692.72 million in FCF in 2025 (compared to $918.15 million in 2024).

As for the guidance, Chord expects about $1.4 billion worth of CAPEX (at midpoint) in 2026 - $50 million higher than 2025 at midpoint - and roughly $700 million in FCF once again when using benchmark prices of $64 per barrel of oil and $3.75 per MMBtu of natural gas, placing them at an attractive P/FCF ratio of about 8.43 today despite the current macro pressures.

As a result of all the recent acquisitions, lateral expansions and efficiency enhancements (~$160 million in annual run-rate savings, or roughly 23% of the FCF expected in 2026), Chord became a very strong Williston Basin producer (largest acreage holder and producer there), as even though they aren’t operating in the best basin, they’re still delivering very solid per share improvements despite the ongoing macro pressure, and I believe the market is still sleeping on it given the valuation, for now, while the CEO highlighted the following during their Q4 Earnings Call:

As we look forward to 2026, Chord's plan builds upon last year's success and remains focused on optimizing capital allocation, generating strong returns and improving continuously. Last year, Chord set a goal of converting 80% of its inventory to long laterals. I'm happy to report that we achieved that goal by year-end 2025, which was earlier than expected, and is a testament to the hard work and dedication of our team.

Financially, based on CHRD’s latest report, we see a strong balance sheet, with a net leverage of ~0.6x as of the latest report, and also no maturities until all the way in 2030 (and 2033), which I believe leaves significant room for more debt if they want to ramp up their expansion through another big acquisition or other developments.

Regarding Chord’s capital returns, I remain a big fan of their balanced approach, with the company prioritizing their balance sheet and leverage over returns, targeting 75%+ of adjusted FCF while the leverage is below 0.5x, 50%+ while the leverage is below 1x (nowadays), or just the base dividend plus potential for other returns when the leverage is above 1x.

As a note, their selected peers currently stand at a leverage of 1.1x, while the SPDR S&P Oil & Gas Expl & Prod ETF (XOP) is at 1.7x, so the fact that they are well below that and are still taking a very careful approach remains yet another factor that highlights their quality, in my opinion.

For the Q4 performance, CHRD has recently declared a $1.30/share quarterly dividend (the base), which places them at a roughly 5% yield today, representing roughly $295 million per year, alongside $10 million in buybacks for the quarter, for a very solid ~48% payout ratio, in line with the target. However, if we assume an improvement in leverage and a 75% payout ratio on the $700 million FCF they expect in 2026, we’re talking about $525 million in total, meaning a yield of roughly 9%, which is not bad at all in such an environment.

Macro Developments

To update a key development started in the previous analysis, I want to begin this segment by quickly mentioning the situation in Venezuela. Under the current conditions, I believe Exxon (XOM) characterized Venezuela’s oil landscape very well when they called it “uninvestable,” as we should keep in mind that it’s true that the country’s oil reserves are massive, but any operations there will require massive investments.

After all, we’re not only talking about one of the heaviest oils on the planet (lots of refining needed), but the infrastructure there is very old, likely the remnants of what American companies left there before they were nationalized (in 1976), with some upgrades made over time. In this oil environment, it’s very hard to find the funds (CAPEX-cutting environment) and the risk appetite to develop something in the country.

Sure, things can improve in the long term and the country is working on an overhaul of their oil industry after Maduro was removed, but nothing guarantees that these operations won’t be taken again or economic conditions won’t change. After all, Trump’s term is over in about 3 years, and we can never know who comes to power next (in either country) and potentially cut the US’ grip that’s just now being developed.

However, there are several other uncertain factors that the market will pay attention to. If things were that simple, then this wouldn’t have been one of the most volatile commodities on the planet, after all. For example, although OPEC+ continued to go for their previously planned halt in production hikes shortly after the Maduro operation, that’s providing some clarity only until the end of Q1, and a switch here can cause pressure on the price of oil once again.

In fact, very recent reports indicate that OPEC+ may decide to raise oil output by 137,000 bpd starting in April 2026 in order to meet peak summer demand, which can be only the beginning of more near-term pressure on the price.

Meanwhile, the situation in Iran is also developing, while the war in Ukraine is taking steps towards an eventual end, which can even lead to somewhat of the opposite of the price jumps, disruptions, and sanctions that came afterward.

Regardless, even before the current situation, we saw J.P. Morgan’s warning saying that we could even see oil drop into the $30s by 2027 in a massive oversupply scenario, which could be terrible for a company like CHRD, as the Williston Basin inventory acquired recently, for example, has a breakeven in the $40s. Indeed, they are improving through acquisitions and the lateral expansion, and this breakeven is a significant upgrade compared to their bankrupt parents, but they would still face issues here.

However, the same J.P. Morgan also has more “normal” outlooks that seem to be in line with OPEC’s halt, estimating Brent prices of $58 and WTI at $54 in 2026, followed by $57 and $53 in 2027, respectively, which still makes CHRD very profitable.

Risks Reiterated

Ultimately, CHRD remains tied to the prices of their commodities, and if we see oil drop to the mid-to-high $50s as JPM expects, we are talking about quite a big drop for CHRD's FCF, as the company's breakeven costs lead to massive swings at these levels, with their FCF yield being estimated at 5% with WTI prices at $55, 16% at $70, and 25% at $85.

This also means that volatility is something we should assume from the start, as the commodity will depend a lot on politics, speculation, outlooks, news, etc., which can lead to rapid swings in near-term valuations.

Valuation

For CHRD’s DCF to Equity valuation, starting from their expected $700 million in FCF in 2026 (assuming average prices of $64 WTI and $3.75 HH for the entire period) without accounting for any change in net borrowings since I want to highlight their “pure” potential.

As a result of the mix of synergies, laterals expansion, and other savings that they're delivering, I'll assume that the CAPEX remains flat at $700 million in 2027 as well, followed by a jump to $1.20 billion in 2028 as the CAPEX could drop and they should be able to reap the benefits of their investments, followed by a CAGR of 3.5% until 2035 and a 2.5% terminal growth rate, with a relatively high discount rate of 12.5% to take into account their basin exposure risks and volatility, with 56.84 million shares outstanding as of their Q4 report.

This way, we get to an equity value of $11.12 billion, for an intrinsic value of $195.68 per share, which is significantly above the current $105.38.

However, I’ll also try to gauge the current market estimates, just to get an idea about the difference between CHRD’s potential and the current valuation. If we start with their $700 million FCF in 2026 and, instead of the previous jump, assume a 4% CAGR until 2030, a 3% CAGR until 2035, and a 2.25% terminal growth rate, with a 15% discount rate and 56.84 million shares outstanding.

This gets us to an intrinsic value of $103.39, which almost perfectly mirrors the current level, taking into account a massive discount rate and weak growth despite the company’s achievements, which I don’t consider correct.

Conclusions

CHRD remains a Strong Buy, being in a very solid financial position, with prudent management that’s been delivering great improvements in recent years and a solid yield on top.

There are risks to keep in mind, as their breakeven costs are still elevated given the basin exposure, but the company is advancing rapidly in a very good direction, transforming significantly since it was formed, which I believe should warrant better valuations going forward.

As a final note, especially given the continued M&A activity seen in the market, I wouldn’t be surprised to see another peer try to acquire CHRD given the valuation, quality, and size.

data.title: Politics And The Markets 02/28/26
data.description:
This is the forum for daily political discussion on Seeking Alpha. A new version is published every market day.

Please don't leave political comments on other articles or posts on the site.

The comments below are not regulated with the same rigor as the rest of the site, and this is an 'enter at your own risk' area as discussion can get very heated. If you can't stand the heat... you know what they say...

More on Today's Markets:

Moderation Guidelines:

We remove comments under the following categories:

  • Personal attacks on another user account
  • Anti-Vaxxer or covid related misinformation
  • Stereotyping, prejudiced or racist language about individuals or the topic under discussion.
  • Inciting violence messages, encouraging hate groups and political violence.

Regardless of which side of the political divide you find yourself, please be courteous and don't direct abuse at other users.

For any issue with regards to comments please email us at : moderation@seekingalpha.com.

Seeking Alpha's Disclosure: Past performance is no guarantee of future results. No recommendation or advice is being given as to whether any investment is suitable for a particular investor. Any views or opinions expressed above may not reflect those of Seeking Alpha as a whole. Seeking Alpha is not a licensed securities dealer, broker or US investment adviser or investment bank. Our analysts are third party authors that include both professional investors and individual investors who may not be licensed or certified by any institute or regulatory body.

data.title: METL: Active Diversified Metals Miners, Up 50% Since Inception In The Past Year
data.description:
Thesis

The parabolic move up in precious metals is known to the entire investing public; however, fewer investors know that mining companies geared towards those commodities have also rallied hard. The market has been focused in the past year on gold miners, while other segments of the investing universe should also have taken some bandwidth. In today's article we are going to explore a fairly new ETF, namely the Sprott Active Metals & Miners ETF (METL). The fund came to market in September 2025 and has soared over +50% since inception.

First the metals soared, then the miners

The geopolitical landscape has been marked by the conflict in Ukraine for the past few years, a conflict that has made central banks around the world aware of the power of sanctions. After the 2022 invasion, Russia's reserves abroad were frozen.

After Russia’s full-scale invasion, the U.S. and its allies froze Russian foreign exchange reserves in their jurisdictions. The Russian Elites, Proxies, and Oligarchs (REPO) Task Force—consisting of the Group of Seven (G7), European Union (EU), and Australia—most recently estimated frozen reserves at $280 billion. Many experts (and the Central Bank of Russia) put the figure between $300 and $330 billion.

This move has made it clear to many foreign countries that dollar- and euro-denominated assets can have the same fate in the case of a conflict. The result? An accelerated move away from treasuries and euro bonds and into precious metals:

As per the chart above, courtesy of Bloomberg, central banks across the world now hold more gold than treasuries.

The net impact on precious metals is fairly easy to see:

While gold and silver were the main beneficiaries, please note the rally in platinum and copper as well. When precious metal prices rally and stay high for a while, it translates into higher profits for the mining companies pulling the metals from the core of the earth. The correlation is not immediate since high gold prices for a short period of time do not translate into solid forward profitability for gold miners. However, when prices stay elevated for a while, miners tend to follow. And they have.

What does METL do?

Let us start with the fund objective for METL:

An actively managed ETF that aims to provide long-term capital appreciation by investing in companies across the metals and mining industry lifecycle, including miners, recyclers, and royalty and streaming companies associated with commodities that are in high global demand. The Fund’s investment strategy is value-oriented and contrarian.

The ETF is therefore an active one that aims to invest in equities of companies involved in the metals and mining lifecycle. Currently the fund composition is as follows:

Copper equities make up the largest proportion of the fund at 29.2%, followed by silver equities at 19.8% and uranium equities at 18%. Please note the allocation to rare earth equities and lithium equities as well. Most of these companies are either large cap or mid cap:

Large and mid caps make up over 76% of the fund holdings, thus leaving small capitalization equities at sub-25%. The largest exposures as of the latest fact sheet are as follows:

Some of the names in the above list are staples of the Global X Silver Miners ETF (SIL). An investor can find the SIL holdings here. Wheaton Precious Metals has a very large representation in SIL but only 3.17% in METL.

METL is much more diversified and allocates capital to copper and rare earth miners and lifecycle companies as opposed to single-segment choices. Note that gold miners are virtually not represented currently, but keep in mind this ETF is active and thus can choose to change holdings as valuations make sense.

Performance

The fund is very new, but we can have a look at how it has done versus some other names in the space:

Since its inception, METL has put in a performance very much in line with the VanEck Gold Miners ETF (GDX) and has underperformed the silver focused SIL. METL is more focused currently on the metal equities next in line for substantial rallies, namely copper and rare earths. We view the fund as a great allocator to the metals space, especially when considering higher prices for longer.

The fund portfolio managers have the flexibility to invest in equities associated with a wide range of metals thus can provide exposure to specific metals potentially positioned for outperformance based on market macro conditions and intrinsic valuation metrics.

Some analytics around this ETF are as follows:

  • AUM: $112 M
  • Expense ratio: 0.89%

The fund does not have enough historical data to generate reliable risk analytics, but given the performance correlation with SIL and GDX, one can safely assume very similar risk statistics for now. METL will be able to generate better analytics long term due to its active management, so we are excited to see the name outperform as we move forward.

Conclusion

METL is a new ETF from Sprott, focused on metals miners across the spectrum. The fund is active and thus can change its composition as it sees fit. The ETF is currently overweight copper and silver miners, with almost no gold miners present in the holdings. The fund has done very well since its recent inception (September 2025), being up over +50%. The name represents a great portfolio diversifier for individuals believing higher metal prices are here to stay for longer.

data.title: Markets Weekly Outlook: Credit Crunch Fears To Conclude A Temperamental Month; NFP Incoming
data.description:
By Elior Manier

Week in review: Markets remain very anxious, and they just found a new reason

It seems traders will have to keep looking for reasons for volatility, as things won't settle anytime soon. Since Kevin Warsh's nomination to head the Federal Reserve, markets have been raging in brutal up-and-down swings.

Despite the harsh narratives, stock benchmarks remain near their all-time highs, and the immediate action looks more like a widespread rebalancing than a full-blown risk dump.

The most speculative assets have been slowly being tossed out since the October risk peaks, and this move is quickly translating into a newfound interest in quality (albeit not yet a real migration).

As some analysts call for a transition to the peak of the economic cycle, defensive assets and sectors are attracting attention. Bonds and metals are actually the best performers this week.

After cryptocurrencies, tech/software, and semiconductors, a more concerning wave is gripping financial markets. Waves of defaults among private equity and some of the most shaky tech companies are dragging down private lenders, venture capital firms, and some financials.

In case you forgot, this comes promptly after credit spreads reached new 2007 lows, and within not even a month, they are coming back to their December highs.

What could be concerning is how highly correlated the financial system has become since the Great Financial Crisis. Banks grew enormously, and it seems people quickly turned the page on the 2023 SVB blow-up, which raised questions about how large a credit spiderweb it has become.

In any case, the monthly picture is a scary one for financials, and that's getting even more amplified today. Bank of America (BAC) is down close to 4%, Goldman Sachs (GS) and Morgan Stanley (MS) are closer to -8%, but that's only the major banks.

Smaller lenders like Blackstone (BX), Jefferies (JEF), and KKR & Co. (KKR) are down close to 30% on the month, and even Robinhood (HOOD) is suffering similar-sized drops. UBS is sending their own warnings, and they're not pretty.

This will surely maintain more anxiety in the markets. It's not that AI will lead to immediate spikes in layoffs; it's more about what happens to those who get replaced and how it spreads through the financial system at this point.

Weekly Performance across Asset Classes

Silver is calling and it wants its crown back! The precious metal is closing well above its early February monthly highs as metals caught a strong bid in today's action. These are preparations for something happening over the weekend.

The Week Ahead: NFP and PMIs all around the globe

Asia Pacific Markets: A condensed data package for APAC

Next week should be exciting for APAC traders. Without counting geopolitics, macro traders will await three PMI reports for China. There has been a surprising drop in the data as of late, and the PBoC is talking about supporting their economy, not through market-wide stimulus but with targeted assistance. It will be interesting to see how it plays out in the data.

The Australian dollar will once again be on the front scene, between inflation surveys, a speech from Governor Bullock, PMIs, trade data and GDP. It's going to be a very essential week for the 2026 FX leader. Let's see if it holds up to the test.

In Japan, traders will be listening closely to Governor Ueda's speech on Monday night. A hike could be coming towards mid-month for the Bank of Japan, and he upped his tone recently regarding the possibility.

With two new decision-makers entering the Bank of Japan in the next months, it could be his last opportunity to build some form of consensus.

Europe and UK Markets: Eurozone and Swiss Inflation

The heavy slate of data also spreads to Europe with inflation data (consumer prices and producer prices) releasing. Friday will also see the yearly data for EU GDP, so keep this one in check.

But the largest culprit will be the Swiss inflation report, where traders should confirm whether negative rates will be a thing or not. A heavy test for FX markets.

North American Markets: More PMIs, but most importantly, non farm payrolls

Next week is going to be huge for North America. Without mentioning Iran, traders will receive a streak of PMIs from Canada and the US. A first round will come on Monday (manufacturing), and the second will be on Wednesday (services), along with the Beige Book (which had been a no-show but is slowly getting interesting).

But markets will have to wait for the real parade: Friday will release a retail sales and non-farm payrolls double-decker at 8:30 A.M. Retail sales sent an honest shocker last month, missing by 0.5 percentage points, while non-farm payrolls remained surprisingly strong. Make sure to not miss our incoming previews.

Now, with a finally timely NFP, participants shall see if this boost in employment really proves to be solid or just a seasonal one (with new year employment).

Even after the latest ease in narrative, keep a close eye on geopolitical developments, particularly those involving the US-Iran talks, as they are likely to continue influencing commodity and broader markets.

Next Week's High-Tier Economic Events

For all market-moving economic releases and events, see the MarketPulse Economic Calendar. (High-tier data only)

Friday 27's Market Wrap

Today's session really continued the past session's turn towards geopolitical hedges and a general turn towards quality. As mentioned in the introduction, banks have seen bloodshed along with tech companies, and this comes right after the gigantic Nvidia earnings.

A very concerning picture of what's coming. Still, stock markets are closing off of their session lows, supported by calmer month-end flows in the afternoon.

The US dollar is also surprisingly at the bottom of the FX board, a victim of some heavy repositioning or month-end settling flows.The CHF leading isn't very surprising, however. Expect to hear about Iran this weekend. Stay safe, everyone!

Safe trades, and enjoy your weekend!

Original Post

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

data.title: SPYD: Momentum Is Now On The High-Yield Factor's Side (Rating Upgrade)
data.description:
Dispersion and diversification have been the market’s passwords ever since the Information Technology sector and Magnificent Seven stocks peaked back in October 2025. Indeed, the State Street SPDR Portfolio S&P 500 High Dividend ETF (SPYD) has been a notable outperformer, as areas like Real Estate and Consumer Staples have posted big alpha.

But it hasn’t been a clear path higher since last April. I had a hold rating on SPYD shortly after Liberation Day. The fund is up 33%, dividends included, but that lags the S&P 500 by about six percentage points. What’s more, SPYD was little changed from my previous assessment to mid-November. It's only been in the last few months that investors have taken a shine to the blue-chip dividend yield factor.

Today, with both a solid valuation and relative strength, I am upgrading SPYD to a buy. I’ll detail the valuation, the holdings, and the chart—all of those factors suggest more upside is to come in 2026.

SYPD Lagged Badly Through October, But Has Gained Major Traction Into 2026

High-Dividend Yield Factor Outperforming

According to the issuer, SPYD seeks to track the performance of the S&P 500 High Dividend Index. It offers a low-cost option to investors seeking both dividend income and potential capital growth. The ETF focuses on the top 80 high-dividend-yielding companies within the S&P 500 Index. SPYD can serve as a core fund for building a diversified portfolio across asset classes.

SPYD is a medium-sized ETF, now with $7.6 billion in assets under management as of February 25, 2026. That’s up from just $6.5 billion at the time of my previous analysis. The annual expense ratio is low at only 7 basis points, while the trailing 12-month dividend yield is high at 4.11%, about 2.9 percentage points above that of the S&P 500.

Share-price momentum has improved markedly just in the last handful of months, now earning the product a B- ETF Grade in that category by Seeking Alpha’s quantitative scoring system (it was a D- back in November). From a risk perspective, SPYD scores decently, but high exposure to cyclical and defensive sectors can bring about a unique set of risks, namely steep negative alpha when the Mag 7 take off.

For now, liquidity is quite strong. Average daily volume is north of 1.8 million shares, while the median 30-day bid/ask spread is very tight at just two basis points, per State Street Funds.

For an update on the portfolio, the 2-star, Gold-rated ETF by Morningstar plots (not surprisingly) on the far-left side of the style box, indicating its weight toward the value style. There is no growth access, while more than 80% of the allocation is classified as SMID-cap by Morningstar.

While the fund is largely unexposed to some of today’s biggest AI risks (as seen in the software industry), macroeconomic factors play a large role in price action. Interest rates are particularly key. In general, the lower Treasury yields go, the more attractive high-yield equities become.

On valuation, SPYD’s price-to-earnings ratio is very compelling at 13.7x, but the long-term earnings growth rate is also modest, near 6%. I would not be surprised to see EPS estimates get taken higher, as broader profit growth cascades across the so-called “real” economy.

SPYD: Portfolio & Factor Profiles

Zooming in on the sector breakdown, Real Estate is by far the largest stake. I consider Real Estate to be like the last frontier of the diversification trade. The property slice of the S&P 500 is right near 52-week highs as its leadership emerges.

Much has also been made of how strong Consumer Staples has been—it, too, is a marked overweight. Financials is close to market weight, and it has lagged badly this year. If banks can regain their footing, that is a notable upside catalyst for SPYD.

And with the ETF’s modified-equal-weight structure, no single stock commands a large position. So, there is diversification from that perspective.

SPYD: Holdings & Dividend Information

With a low P/E and much better price action, SPYD’s seasonality is not ideal today. March has occasionally featured increased volatility, while modest gains have occurred, on average, in April and May. Keep in mind that the below view is for price-only returns (dividends are not included).

SPYD: Muted Seasonal Trends

The Technical Take

Given the solid valuation and impressive relative strength, SPYD’s technicals check out well. Notice in the chart below that the fund is right near all-time highs. It scaled the November 2024 previous high-water mark after surging from November through the turn of this year. Now, with a rising long-term 200-day moving average, the bulls clearly control the primary trend. Price is above the 50 dma, which is higher than the 200 dma.

Also take a look at the volume by price profile on the left side of the graph. There should be major support if we see a pullback. For now, support is right near the current price, with a firmer layer between $45 and $45. I expect the current bull flag pattern to resolve higher, and it makes sense that the ETF is working off technical overbought conditions (as evidenced by the RSI momentum oscillator at the top of the chart).

In terms of an upside target, a measured move objective to $67 is in play based on the depth of the Q4 2024 to April 2025 decline and subsequent breakout.

SPYD: Bullish Upside Breakout, Bull Flag, Rising 200dma

The Bottom Line

I have a buy rating on SPYD. I see much-improved momentum, relative strength, and technicals. Fundamentally, the valuation is very low, while the high-dividend yield factor has grabbed leadership in today’s more-diversified market.
